content.webTitle: In praise of … the weave | Editorial

fields.headline: In praise of … the weave
fields.bodyText: The American press calls them hair plugs. But after Wayne Rooney's header gave England victory on Tuesday, it had to be weaves or the Sun couldn't say weave won it (though it could still have had the excellent thatch of the day). And weaves have credibility; hair plugs sound a bit horticultural, no look for a sporting icon. There may or may not be physics in it – the web is quiet on the question of how far mass and velocity of elastic collisions are influenced by head covering – but there are surely times when psychology matters more than Newtonian formulae. So if Rooney is prepared to spend £30,000 on moving hair from the back of his head to the top, other than by the traditional combover favoured by Stanley Matthews, then clearly having hair has a Samsonian influence on his game. Beckham had his Alice band, Carroll has his ponytail. On Tuesday it took the Rooney follicles three goes to get it right. Now we've got Italy...
